trans-unit.source: The partitioning schemes described in this guidance are explained in a way that is independent of the underlying data storage technology.
trans-unit.target: The partitioning schemes described in this guidance are explained in a way that is independent of the underlying data storage technology.

trans-unit.source: The three typical strategies for partitioning data are:
trans-unit.target: The three typical strategies for partitioning data are:

trans-unit.source: Horizontal partitioning (often called sharding).
trans-unit.target: Horizontal partitioning (often called sharding).

trans-unit.source: In this strategy each partition is a data store in its own right, but all partitions have the same schema.
trans-unit.target: In this strategy each partition is a data store in its own right, but all partitions have the same schema.

trans-unit.source: Each partition is known as a shard and holds a specific subset of the data, such as all the orders for a specific set of customers in an ecommerce application.
trans-unit.target: Each partition is known as a shard and holds a specific subset of the data, such as all the orders for a specific set of customers in an ecommerce application.

trans-unit.source: Vertical partitioning.
trans-unit.target: Vertical partitioning.

trans-unit.source: In this strategy each partition holds a subset of the fields for items in the data store.
trans-unit.target: In this strategy each partition holds a subset of the fields for items in the data store.

trans-unit.source: The fields are divided according to their pattern of use, such as placing the frequently accessed fields in one vertical partition and the less frequently accessed fields in another.
trans-unit.target: The fields are divided according to their pattern of use, such as placing the frequently accessed fields in one vertical partition and the less frequently accessed fields in another.

trans-unit.source: Functional partitioning.
trans-unit.target: Functional partitioning.

trans-unit.source: In this strategy data is aggregated according to how it is used by each bounded context in the system.
trans-unit.target: In this strategy data is aggregated according to how it is used by each bounded context in the system.

trans-unit.source: For example, an ecommerce system that implements separate business functions for invoicing and managing product inventory might store invoice data in one partition and product inventory data in another.
trans-unit.target: For example, an ecommerce system that implements separate business functions for invoicing and managing product inventory might store invoice data in one partition and product inventory data in another.

trans-unit.source: It’s important to note that the three strategies described here can be combined.
trans-unit.target: It’s important to note that the three strategies described here can be combined.

trans-unit.source: They are not mutually exclusive and you should consider them all when you design a partitioning scheme.
trans-unit.target: They are not mutually exclusive and you should consider them all when you design a partitioning scheme.

trans-unit.source: For example, you might divide data into shards and then use vertical partitioning to further subdivide the data in each shard.
trans-unit.target: For example, you might divide data into shards and then use vertical partitioning to further subdivide the data in each shard.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the data in a functional partition may be split into shards (which may also be vertically partitioned).
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the data in a functional partition may be split into shards (which may also be vertically partitioned).

trans-unit.source: However, the differing requirements of each strategy can raise a number of conflicting issues that you must evaluate and balance when designing a partitioning scheme that meets the overall data processing performance targets for your system.

trans-unit.source: The partitioning scheme that you implement can have a significant bearing on the performance of your system, and also affect the rate at which shards have to be added or removed or the data repartitioned across shards.
trans-unit.target: The partitioning scheme that you implement can have a significant bearing on the performance of your system, and also affect the rate at which shards have to be added or removed or the data repartitioned across shards.

trans-unit.source: You should consider the following points when using Elastic Scale to partition data:
trans-unit.target: You should consider the following points when using Elastic Scale to partition data:

trans-unit.source: Group data that is used together into the same shard and avoid operations that need to access data held in multiple shards.
trans-unit.target: Group data that is used together into the same shard and avoid operations that need to access data held in multiple shards.

trans-unit.source: Bear in mind that with Elastic Scale a shard is a SQL database in its own right, and Azure SQL Database does not support cross-database joins; these operations have to be performed on the client-side.
trans-unit.target: Bear in mind that with Elastic Scale a shard is a SQL database in its own right, and Azure SQL Database does not support cross-database joins; these operations have to be performed on the client-side.

trans-unit.source: Also remember that with Azure SQL Database referential integrity constraints, triggers, and stored procedures in one database cannot reference objects in another, so don't design a system that has dependencies between shards.
trans-unit.target: Also remember that with Azure SQL Database referential integrity constraints, triggers, and stored procedures in one database cannot reference objects in another, so don't design a system that has dependencies between shards.

trans-unit.source: However, a SQL database can contain tables holding copies of reference data frequently used by queries and other operations, and these tables do not have to belong to any specific shardlet.
trans-unit.target: However, a SQL database can contain tables holding copies of reference data frequently used by queries and other operations, and these tables do not have to belong to any specific shardlet.

trans-unit.source: Replicating this data across shards can help to remove the need to join data that spans databases.
trans-unit.target: Replicating this data across shards can help to remove the need to join data that spans databases.

trans-unit.source: Ideally, such data should be static or slow-moving to minimize the replication effort and reduce the chances of it becoming stale.
trans-unit.target: Ideally, such data should be static or slow-moving to minimize the replication effort and reduce the chances of it becoming stale.

trans-unit.source: Although Azure SQL Database does not support cross-database joins, the Elastic Scale API enables you to perform cross-shard queries that can transparently iterate through the data held in all the shardlets referenced by a shard map.
trans-unit.target: Although Azure SQL Database does not support cross-database joins, the Elastic Scale API enables you to perform cross-shard queries that can transparently iterate through the data held in all the shardlets referenced by a shard map.

trans-unit.source: The Elastic Scale API breaks cross-shard queries down into a series of individual queries (one for each database) and then merges the results together.
trans-unit.target: The Elastic Scale API breaks cross-shard queries down into a series of individual queries (one for each database) and then merges the results together.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <linkText>Multi-Shard Querying</linkText><title></title> page on the Microsoft website.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <linkText>Multi-Shard Querying</linkText><title></title> page on the Microsoft website.

trans-unit.source: The data stored in shardlets that belong to the same shard map should have the same schema.
trans-unit.target: The data stored in shardlets that belong to the same shard map should have the same schema.

trans-unit.source: For example, don't create a list shard map that points to some shardlets containing tenant data and other shardlets containing product information.
trans-unit.target: For example, don't create a list shard map that points to some shardlets containing tenant data and other shardlets containing product information.

trans-unit.source: This rule is not enforced by Elastic Scale, but data management and querying becomes very complex if each shardlet has a different schema.
trans-unit.target: This rule is not enforced by Elastic Scale, but data management and querying becomes very complex if each shardlet has a different schema.

trans-unit.source: In the example just cited, you should create two list shard maps; one referencing tenant data and the other point to product information.
trans-unit.target: In the example just cited, you should create two list shard maps; one referencing tenant data and the other point to product information.

trans-unit.source: Remember that the data belonging to different shardlets can be stored in the same shard.
trans-unit.target: Remember that the data belonging to different shardlets can be stored in the same shard.

trans-unit.source: The cross-shard query functionality of the Elastic Scale API depends on each shardlet in the shard map containing the same schema.
trans-unit.target: The cross-shard query functionality of the Elastic Scale API depends on each shardlet in the shard map containing the same schema.

trans-unit.source: Transactional operations are only supported for data held within the same shard, and not across shards.
trans-unit.target: Transactional operations are only supported for data held within the same shard, and not across shards.

trans-unit.source: Transactions can span shardlets as long as they are part of the same shard.
trans-unit.target: Transactions can span shardlets as long as they are part of the same shard.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, if your business logic needs to perform transactions, either store the affected data in the same shard or implement eventual consistency.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, if your business logic needs to perform transactions, either store the affected data in the same shard or implement eventual consistency.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the Data Consistency guidance.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the Data Consistency guidance.

trans-unit.source: Place shards near to the users that access the data in those shards (geo-locate shards).
trans-unit.target: Place shards near to the users that access the data in those shards (geo-locate shards).

trans-unit.source: This strategy will help to reduce latency.
trans-unit.target: This strategy will help to reduce latency.

trans-unit.source: Avoid having a mixture of highly active (hotspots) and relatively inactive shards.
trans-unit.target: Avoid having a mixture of highly active (hotspots) and relatively inactive shards.

trans-unit.source: Try and spread the load evenly across shards.
trans-unit.target: Try and spread the load evenly across shards.

trans-unit.source: This may require hashing the shardlet keys.
trans-unit.target: This may require hashing the shardlet keys.

trans-unit.source: If you are geo-locating shards, make sure that the hashed keys map to shardlets held in shards stored close to the users that access that data.
trans-unit.target: If you are geo-locating shards, make sure that the hashed keys map to shardlets held in shards stored close to the users that access that data.

trans-unit.source: Currently, only a limited set of SQL data types are supported as shardlet keys; int, bigint, varbinary, and uniqueidentifier.
trans-unit.target: Currently, only a limited set of SQL data types are supported as shardlet keys; int, bigint, varbinary, and uniqueidentifier.

trans-unit.target: The SQL int and bigint types correspond to the int and long data types in C#, and have the same ranges.

trans-unit.source: As the name implies, Elastic Scale enables a system to add and remove shards as the volume of data shrinks and grows.
trans-unit.target: As the name implies, Elastic Scale enables a system to add and remove shards as the volume of data shrinks and grows.

trans-unit.source: The APIs in the Azure SQL Database Elastic Scale Client Library enable an application to create and delete shards dynamically (and transparently update the shard-map manager), but removing a shard is a destructive operation that also requires deleting all the data in that shard.
trans-unit.target: The APIs in the Azure SQL Database Elastic Scale Client Library enable an application to create and delete shards dynamically (and transparently update the shard-map manager), but removing a shard is a destructive operation that also requires deleting all the data in that shard.

trans-unit.target: If an application needs to split a shard into two separate shards or combine shards together, Elastic Scale provides a separate Split/Merge service.

trans-unit.source: This service runs in a cloud-hosted service (the developer has to create this cloud-hosted service), and takes care of migrating data between shards safely.

trans-unit.source: Azure storage provides three abstractions for managing data:
trans-unit.target: Azure storage provides three abstractions for managing data:

trans-unit.source: Table Storage, which implements scalable structure storage.
trans-unit.target: Table Storage, which implements scalable structure storage.

trans-unit.source: A table contains a collection of entities, each of which can comprise a set of properties and values.
trans-unit.target: A table contains a collection of entities, each of which can comprise a set of properties and values.

trans-unit.source: Blob Storage, which supplies storage for large objects and files.
trans-unit.target: Blob Storage, which supplies storage for large objects and files.

trans-unit.source: Storage Queues, which support reliable asynchronous messaging between applications.
trans-unit.target: Storage Queues, which support reliable asynchronous messaging between applications.

trans-unit.source: Table Storage and Blob Storage are essentially key-value stores optimized to hold structured and unstructured data respectively.
trans-unit.target: Table Storage and Blob Storage are essentially key-value stores optimized to hold structured and unstructured data respectively.

trans-unit.source: Storage Queues provide a mechanism for building loosely coupled, scalable applications.
trans-unit.target: Storage Queues provide a mechanism for building loosely coupled, scalable applications.

trans-unit.source: Table Storage, Blob Storage, and Storage Queues are created within the context of an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Table Storage, Blob Storage, and Storage Queues are created within the context of an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: Azure storage accounts support three forms of redundancy:
trans-unit.target: Azure storage accounts support three forms of redundancy:

trans-unit.source: Locally redundant storage, which maintains three copies of data within a single datacenter.
trans-unit.target: Locally redundant storage, which maintains three copies of data within a single datacenter.

trans-unit.source: This form of redundancy protects against hardware failure but not against a disaster that encompasses the entire datacenter.
trans-unit.target: This form of redundancy protects against hardware failure but not against a disaster that encompasses the entire datacenter.

trans-unit.source: Zone-redundant storage which maintains three copies of data spread across different datacenters within the same region (or across two geographically close regions).
trans-unit.target: Zone-redundant storage which maintains three copies of data spread across different datacenters within the same region (or across two geographically close regions).

trans-unit.source: This form of redundancy can protect against disasters that occur within a single datacenter, but cannot protect against large-scale network disconnects that affect an entire region.
trans-unit.target: This form of redundancy can protect against disasters that occur within a single datacenter, but cannot protect against large-scale network disconnects that affect an entire region.

trans-unit.source: Note that zone-redundant storage is only currently only available for block blobs.
trans-unit.target: Note that zone-redundant storage is only currently only available for block blobs.

trans-unit.source: Geo-redundant storage, which maintains six copies of data; three copies in one region (your local region), and another three copies in a remote region.
trans-unit.target: Geo-redundant storage, which maintains six copies of data; three copies in one region (your local region), and another three copies in a remote region.

trans-unit.source: This form of redundancy provides the highest level of disaster protection.
trans-unit.target: This form of redundancy provides the highest level of disaster protection.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft has published scalability targets for Azure storage accounts; see the page <linkText>Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets</linkText><title></title> on the Microsoft website.

trans-unit.source: Azure table storage is a key/value stored designed around partitioning.
trans-unit.target: Azure table storage is a key/value stored designed around partitioning.

trans-unit.source: All entities are stored in a partition, and partitions are managed internally by Azure table storage.
trans-unit.target: All entities are stored in a partition, and partitions are managed internally by Azure table storage.

trans-unit.source: Each entity stored in a table must provide a two-part key comprising:
trans-unit.target: Each entity stored in a table must provide a two-part key comprising:

trans-unit.source: The partition key.
trans-unit.target: The partition key.

trans-unit.source: This is a string values that determines in which partition Azure table storage will place the entity.
trans-unit.target: This is a string values that determines in which partition Azure table storage will place the entity.

trans-unit.source: All entities with the same partition key will be stored in the same partition.
trans-unit.target: All entities with the same partition key will be stored in the same partition.

trans-unit.source: The row key.
trans-unit.target: The row key.

trans-unit.source: This is another string value that identifies the entity within the partition.
trans-unit.target: This is another string value that identifies the entity within the partition.

trans-unit.source: All entities within a partition are sorted lexically, in ascending order, by this key.
trans-unit.target: All entities within a partition are sorted lexically, in ascending order, by this key.

trans-unit.source: The partition key/row key combination must be unique for each entity and cannot exceed 1KB in length.
trans-unit.target: The partition key/row key combination must be unique for each entity and cannot exceed 1KB in length.

trans-unit.source: The remainder of the data for an entity consists of application-defined fields.
trans-unit.target: The remainder of the data for an entity consists of application-defined fields.

trans-unit.source: No particular schemas are enforced, and each row can contain a different set of application-defined fields.
trans-unit.target: No particular schemas are enforced, and each row can contain a different set of application-defined fields.

trans-unit.source: The only limitation is that the maximum size of an entity (including the partition and row keys) is currently 1MB.
trans-unit.target: The only limitation is that the maximum size of an entity (including the partition and row keys) is currently 1MB.

trans-unit.source: The maximum size of a table is 200TB, although these figures may change in the future (check the page <linkText>Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets</linkText><title></title> on the Microsoft website for the most recent information about these limits.
trans-unit.target: The maximum size of a table is 200TB, although these figures may change in the future (check the page <linkText>Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets</linkText><title></title> on the Microsoft website for the most recent information about these limits.

trans-unit.source: If you are attempting to store entities that exceed this capacity, then consider splitting them into multiple tables; use vertical partitioning and divide the fields into the groups that are most likely to be accessed together.
trans-unit.target: If you are attempting to store entities that exceed this capacity, then consider splitting them into multiple tables; use vertical partitioning and divide the fields into the groups that are most likely to be accessed together.

trans-unit.source: Azure table storage also adds a timestamp field to each entity.
trans-unit.target: Azure table storage also adds a timestamp field to each entity.

trans-unit.source: The timestamp field is maintained by table storage and is updated each time the entity is modified and written back to a partition.
trans-unit.target: The timestamp field is maintained by table storage and is updated each time the entity is modified and written back to a partition.

trans-unit.source: The table storage service uses this field to implement optimistic concurrency (each time an application writes an entity back to table storage, the table storage service compares the value of the timestamp in the entity being written with the value held in table storage, and if they are different another application must have modified the entity since it was retrieved and the write operation fails).
trans-unit.target: The table storage service uses this field to implement optimistic concurrency (each time an application writes an entity back to table storage, the table storage service compares the value of the timestamp in the entity being written with the value held in table storage, and if they are different another application must have modified the entity since it was retrieved and the write operation fails).

trans-unit.source: You should not modify this field in your own code, and neither should you specify a value for this field when you create a new entity.

trans-unit.source: Azure table storage uses the partition key to determine how to store the data.
trans-unit.target: Azure table storage uses the partition key to determine how to store the data.

trans-unit.source: If an entity is added to a table with a previously unused partition key, Azure table storage will create a new partition for this entity.
trans-unit.target: If an entity is added to a table with a previously unused partition key, Azure table storage will create a new partition for this entity.

trans-unit.source: Other entities with the same partition key will be stored in the same partition.
trans-unit.target: Other entities with the same partition key will be stored in the same partition.

trans-unit.source: This mechanism effectively implements an automatic scale-out strategy.
trans-unit.target: This mechanism effectively implements an automatic scale-out strategy.

trans-unit.source: Each partition will be stored on a single server in an Azure datacenter (to help ensure that queries that retrieve data from a single partition run quickly), but different partitions can be distributed across multiple servers.
trans-unit.target: Each partition will be stored on a single server in an Azure datacenter (to help ensure that queries that retrieve data from a single partition run quickly), but different partitions can be distributed across multiple servers.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, a single server can host multiple partitions if these partitions are limited in size.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, a single server can host multiple partitions if these partitions are limited in size.

trans-unit.source: You should consider the following points when you design your entities for Azure table storage:
trans-unit.target: You should consider the following points when you design your entities for Azure table storage:

trans-unit.source: The selection of partition key and row key values should be driven by the way in which the data is accessed.
trans-unit.target: The selection of partition key and row key values should be driven by the way in which the data is accessed.

trans-unit.source: You should choose a partition key/row key combination that supports the majority of your queries.
trans-unit.target: You should choose a partition key/row key combination that supports the majority of your queries.

trans-unit.source: The most efficient queries will retrieve data by specifying the partition key and the row key.
trans-unit.target: The most efficient queries will retrieve data by specifying the partition key and the row key.

trans-unit.source: Queries that specify a partition key and a range of row keys can be satisfied by scanning a single partition; this is relatively fast because the data is held in row key order.
trans-unit.target: Queries that specify a partition key and a range of row keys can be satisfied by scanning a single partition; this is relatively fast because the data is held in row key order.

trans-unit.source: Queries that don't at least specify the partition key may require Azure table storage to scan every partition for your data.
trans-unit.target: Queries that don't at least specify the partition key may require Azure table storage to scan every partition for your data.

trans-unit.source: If an entity has one natural key, then use it as the partition key and specify an empty string as the row key.
trans-unit.target: If an entity has one natural key, then use it as the partition key and specify an empty string as the row key.

trans-unit.source: If an entity has a composite key comprising two properties, select the slowest changing property as the partition key and the other as the row key.
trans-unit.target: If an entity has a composite key comprising two properties, select the slowest changing property as the partition key and the other as the row key.

trans-unit.source: If an entity has more than two key properties, use a concatenation of properties to provide the partition and row keys.
trans-unit.target: If an entity has more than two key properties, use a concatenation of properties to provide the partition and row keys.

trans-unit.source: If you regularly perform queries that look up data using fields other than the partition and row keys, consider implementing the <linkText>Index Table Pattern</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you regularly perform queries that look up data using fields other than the partition and row keys, consider implementing the <linkText>Index Table Pattern</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you generate partition keys using a monotonic increasing or decreasing sequence (such as "0001", "0002", "0003", …)
trans-unit.target: If you generate partition keys using a monotonic increasing or decreasing sequence (such as "0001", "0002", "0003", …)

trans-unit.source: and each partition only contains a limited amount of data, then Azure table storage may physically group these partitions together on the same server.
trans-unit.target: and each partition only contains a limited amount of data, then Azure table storage may physically group these partitions together on the same server.

trans-unit.source: This mechanism assumes that the application is most likely to perform queries across a contiguous range of partitions (range queries) and is optimized for this case.
trans-unit.target: This mechanism assumes that the application is most likely to perform queries across a contiguous range of partitions (range queries) and is optimized for this case.

trans-unit.source: However, this approach can lead to hotspots focused on a single server as all inserts of new entities will likely be concentrated at one or other end of the contiguous ranges.
trans-unit.target: However, this approach can lead to hotspots focused on a single server as all inserts of new entities will likely be concentrated at one or other end of the contiguous ranges.

trans-unit.source: It can also reduce scalability.
trans-unit.target: It can also reduce scalability.

trans-unit.source: To spread the load more evenly across servers, consider hashing the partition key to make the sequence more random.
trans-unit.target: To spread the load more evenly across servers, consider hashing the partition key to make the sequence more random.

trans-unit.source: Azure table storage supports transactional operations for entities that belong to the same partition.
trans-unit.target: Azure table storage supports transactional operations for entities that belong to the same partition.

trans-unit.source: This means that an application can perform multiple insert, update, delete, replace, or merge operations as an atomic unit (subject to the transaction not including more than 100 entities and the payload of the request not exceeding 4MB in size).
trans-unit.target: This means that an application can perform multiple insert, update, delete, replace, or merge operations as an atomic unit (subject to the transaction not including more than 100 entities and the payload of the request not exceeding 4MB in size).

trans-unit.source: Operations that span multiple partitions are not transactional, and may require you to implement eventual consistency as described by the Data Consistency Guidance.
trans-unit.target: Operations that span multiple partitions are not transactional, and may require you to implement eventual consistency as described by the Data Consistency Guidance.

trans-unit.source: For more information about table storage and transactions, visit the <linkText>Performing Entity Group Transactions</linkText><title></title> page on the Microsoft website.
trans-unit.target: For more information about table storage and transactions, visit the <linkText>Performing Entity Group Transactions</linkText><title></title> page on the Microsoft website.

trans-unit.source: Give careful attention to the granularity of the partition key:
trans-unit.target: Give careful attention to the granularity of the partition key:

trans-unit.source: Using the same partition key for every entity will cause the table storage service to create a single large partition held on one server preventing it from scaling out and instead focusing the load on a single server.
trans-unit.target: Using the same partition key for every entity will cause the table storage service to create a single large partition held on one server preventing it from scaling out and instead focusing the load on a single server.

trans-unit.source: As a result, this approach is only suitable for systems that manage a small number of entities.
trans-unit.target: As a result, this approach is only suitable for systems that manage a small number of entities.

trans-unit.source: However, this approach does ensure that all entities can participate in entity group transactions.
trans-unit.target: However, this approach does ensure that all entities can participate in entity group transactions.

trans-unit.source: Using a unique partition key for every entity will cause the table storage service to create a separate partition for each entity, possibly resulting in a large number of small partitions (depending on the size of the entities).
trans-unit.target: Using a unique partition key for every entity will cause the table storage service to create a separate partition for each entity, possibly resulting in a large number of small partitions (depending on the size of the entities).

trans-unit.source: This approach is more scalable than using a single partition key, but entity group transactions are not possible and queries that fetch more than one entity may involve reading from more than one server.
trans-unit.target: This approach is more scalable than using a single partition key, but entity group transactions are not possible and queries that fetch more than one entity may involve reading from more than one server.

trans-unit.source: However, if the application performs range queries then using a monotonic sequence to generate the partition keys might help to optimize these queries.
trans-unit.target: However, if the application performs range queries then using a monotonic sequence to generate the partition keys might help to optimize these queries.

trans-unit.source: Sharing the partition key across a subset of entities enables you to group related entities in the same partition.
trans-unit.target: Sharing the partition key across a subset of entities enables you to group related entities in the same partition.

trans-unit.source: Operations that involve related entities can be performed by using entity group transactions, and queries that fetch a set of related entities may be satisfied by accessing a single server.
trans-unit.target: Operations that involve related entities can be performed by using entity group transactions, and queries that fetch a set of related entities may be satisfied by accessing a single server.

trans-unit.source: For additional information on partitioning data in Azure table storage, see the article <linkText>Designing a Scalable Partitioning Strategy for Azure Table Storage</linkText><title></title> on the Microsoft website.
trans-unit.target: For additional information on partitioning data in Azure table storage, see the article <linkText>Designing a Scalable Partitioning Strategy for Azure Table Storage</linkText><title></title> on the Microsoft website.

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob Storage enables you to hold large binary objects, currently up to 200GB in size for block blobs, or 1TB for page blobs (for the most recent information, visit the <linkText>Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets</linkText><title></title> page on the Microsoft website).
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob Storage enables you to hold large binary objects, currently up to 200GB in size for block blobs, or 1TB for page blobs (for the most recent information, visit the <linkText>Azure Storage Scalability and Performance Targets</linkText><title></title> page on the Microsoft website).

trans-unit.source: Use block blobs in scenarios such as streaming where you need to upload or download large volumes of data quickly.

trans-unit.source: Each blob (either block or page) is held in a container in an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Each blob (either block or page) is held in a container in an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: You can use containers to group related blobs that have the same security requirements together, although this grouping is logical rather than physical.
trans-unit.target: You can use containers to group related blobs that have the same security requirements together, although this grouping is logical rather than physical.

trans-unit.source: Inside a container each blob has a unique name.
trans-unit.target: Inside a container each blob has a unique name.

trans-unit.source: Blob storage is automatically partitioned based on the blob name.
trans-unit.target: Blob storage is automatically partitioned based on the blob name.

trans-unit.source: Each blob is held in its own partition, and blobs in the same container do not share a partition.
trans-unit.target: Each blob is held in its own partition, and blobs in the same container do not share a partition.

trans-unit.source: This architecture enables Azure blob storage to balance the load across servers transparently as different blobs in the same container may be distributed across different servers.

trans-unit.source: Azure storage queues enable you to implement asynchronous messaging between processes.
trans-unit.target: Azure storage queues enable you to implement asynchronous messaging between processes.

trans-unit.source: An Azure storage account can contain any number of queues, and each queue can contain any number of messages.
trans-unit.target: An Azure storage account can contain any number of queues, and each queue can contain any number of messages.

trans-unit.source: The only limitation is the space available in the storage account.
trans-unit.target: The only limitation is the space available in the storage account.

trans-unit.source: The maximum size of an individual message is 64KB.
trans-unit.target: The maximum size of an individual message is 64KB.

trans-unit.source: If you require messages bigger than this, then consider using Azure Service Bus queues instead.
trans-unit.target: If you require messages bigger than this, then consider using Azure Service Bus queues instead.

trans-unit.source: Each storage queue has a unique name within the storage account in which it is contained.
trans-unit.target: Each storage queue has a unique name within the storage account in which it is contained.

trans-unit.source: Azure partitions queues based on the name, and all messages for the same queue are stored in the same partition, controlled by a single server.
trans-unit.target: Azure partitions queues based on the name, and all messages for the same queue are stored in the same partition, controlled by a single server.

trans-unit.source: Different queues can be managed by different servers to help balance the load.
trans-unit.target: Different queues can be managed by different servers to help balance the load.

trans-unit.source: The allocation of queues to servers is transparent to applications and users.
trans-unit.target: The allocation of queues to servers is transparent to applications and users.

trans-unit.source: In a large scale application, don't use the same storage queue for all instances of the application as this approach may cause the server hosting the queue to become a hotspot; use different queues for different functional areas of the application.
trans-unit.target: In a large scale application, don't use the same storage queue for all instances of the application as this approach may cause the server hosting the queue to become a hotspot; use different queues for different functional areas of the application.

trans-unit.source: Azure storage queues do not support transactions, so directing messages to different queues should have little impact on messaging consistency.
trans-unit.target: Azure storage queues do not support transactions, so directing messages to different queues should have little impact on messaging consistency.

trans-unit.source: An Azure storage queue can handle up to 2000 messages per second.
trans-unit.target: An Azure storage queue can handle up to 2000 messages per second.

trans-unit.source: If you need to process messages at a greater rate than this then consider creating multiple queues.
trans-unit.target: If you need to process messages at a greater rate than this then consider creating multiple queues.

trans-unit.source: For example, in a global application, create separate storage queues in separate storage accounts to handle application instances running in each region.
trans-unit.target: For example, in a global application, create separate storage queues in separate storage accounts to handle application instances running in each region.

trans-unit.source: Azure Service Bus uses a message broker to handle messages sent to a Service Bus queue or topic.
trans-unit.target: Azure Service Bus uses a message broker to handle messages sent to a Service Bus queue or topic.

trans-unit.source: By default, all messages sent to a queue or topic are handled by the same message broker process.
trans-unit.target: By default, all messages sent to a queue or topic are handled by the same message broker process.

trans-unit.source: This architecture can place a limitation on the overall throughput of the message queue.
trans-unit.target: This architecture can place a limitation on the overall throughput of the message queue.

trans-unit.source: However, you can also partition a queue or topic when it is created by setting the EnablePartitioning property of the queue or topic description to true.
trans-unit.target: However, you can also partition a queue or topic when it is created by setting the EnablePartitioning property of the queue or topic description to true.

trans-unit.source: A partitioned queue or topic is divided up into multiple fragments, each of which is backed by a separate message store and message broker.
trans-unit.target: A partitioned queue or topic is divided up into multiple fragments, each of which is backed by a separate message store and message broker.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus takes responsibility for creating and managing these fragments.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus takes responsibility for creating and managing these fragments.

trans-unit.source: When an application posts a message to a partitioned queue or topic, Service Bus assigns the message to a fragment for that queue or topic.
trans-unit.target: When an application posts a message to a partitioned queue or topic, Service Bus assigns the message to a fragment for that queue or topic.

trans-unit.source: When an application receives a message from a queue or subscription, Service Bus checks each fragment for the next available message and then passes it to the application for processing.
trans-unit.target: When an application receives a message from a queue or subscription, Service Bus checks each fragment for the next available message and then passes it to the application for processing.

trans-unit.source: This structure helps to distribute the load across message brokers and message stores, increasing scalability and improving availability; if the message broker or message store for one fragment is temporarily unavailable, Service Bus can retrieve messages from one of the remaining available fragments.
trans-unit.target: This structure helps to distribute the load across message brokers and message stores, increasing scalability and improving availability; if the message broker or message store for one fragment is temporarily unavailable, Service Bus can retrieve messages from one of the remaining available fragments.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus assigns a message to a fragment as follows:
trans-unit.target: Service Bus assigns a message to a fragment as follows:

trans-unit.source: If the message belongs to a session, all messages with the same value for the _ SessionId_ property are sent to the same fragment.
trans-unit.target: If the message belongs to a session, all messages with the same value for the _ SessionId_ property are sent to the same fragment.

trans-unit.source: If the message does not belong to a session but the sender has specified a value for the PartitionKey property, then all messages with the same PartitionKey value are send to the same fragment.
trans-unit.target: If the message does not belong to a session but the sender has specified a value for the PartitionKey property, then all messages with the same PartitionKey value are send to the same fragment.

trans-unit.source: If the SessionId and PartitionKey properties are both specified, then they must be set to the same value otherwise the message will be rejected.
trans-unit.target: If the SessionId and PartitionKey properties are both specified, then they must be set to the same value otherwise the message will be rejected.

trans-unit.source: If the SessionId and PartitionKey properties for a message are not specified, but duplicate detection is enabled, the MessageId property will be used.
trans-unit.target: If the SessionId and PartitionKey properties for a message are not specified, but duplicate detection is enabled, the MessageId property will be used.

trans-unit.source: All messages with the same MessageId will be directed to the same fragment.
trans-unit.target: All messages with the same MessageId will be directed to the same fragment.

trans-unit.source: If messages do not include a SessionId, PartitionKey, or MessageId property, then Service Bus assigns messages to fragments in a round-robin fashion.
trans-unit.target: If messages do not include a SessionId, PartitionKey, or MessageId property, then Service Bus assigns messages to fragments in a round-robin fashion.

trans-unit.source: If a fragment is unavailable, Service Bus will move on to the next.
trans-unit.target: If a fragment is unavailable, Service Bus will move on to the next.

trans-unit.source: In this way, a temporary fault in the messaging infrastructure does not cause the message-send operation to fail.
trans-unit.target: In this way, a temporary fault in the messaging infrastructure does not cause the message-send operation to fail.

trans-unit.source: You should consider the following points when deciding and how, or whether, to partition a Service Bus message queue or topic:
trans-unit.target: You should consider the following points when deciding and how, or whether, to partition a Service Bus message queue or topic:

trans-unit.source: Service Bus queues and topics are created within the scope of a Service Bus namespace.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus queues and topics are created within the scope of a Service Bus namespace.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus currently allows up to 100 partitioned queues or topics per namespace.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus currently allows up to 100 partitioned queues or topics per namespace.

trans-unit.source: Each Service Bus namespace imposes quotas on the resources available, such as the number of subscriptions per topic, the number of concurrent send and receive requests per second, and the maximum number of concurrent connections that can be established.
trans-unit.target: Each Service Bus namespace imposes quotas on the resources available, such as the number of subscriptions per topic, the number of concurrent send and receive requests per second, and the maximum number of concurrent connections that can be established.

trans-unit.source: These quotas are documented on the Microsoft website on the page <linkText>Service Bus Quotas</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: These quotas are documented on the Microsoft website on the page <linkText>Service Bus Quotas</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you expect to exceed these values, then create additional namespaces with their own queues and topics, and spread the work across these namespaces.
trans-unit.target: If you expect to exceed these values, then create additional namespaces with their own queues and topics, and spread the work across these namespaces.

trans-unit.source: For example, in a global application, create separate namespaces in each region and configure application instances to use the queues and topics in the nearest namespace.
trans-unit.target: For example, in a global application, create separate namespaces in each region and configure application instances to use the queues and topics in the nearest namespace.

trans-unit.source: Messages that are sent as part of a transaction must specify a partition key.
trans-unit.target: Messages that are sent as part of a transaction must specify a partition key.

trans-unit.source: This can be a SessionId, PartitionKey, or MessageId.
trans-unit.target: This can be a SessionId, PartitionKey, or MessageId.

trans-unit.source: All messages that are sent as part of the same transaction must specify the same partition key because they must be handled by the same message broker process.
trans-unit.target: All messages that are sent as part of the same transaction must specify the same partition key because they must be handled by the same message broker process.

trans-unit.source: You cannot send messages to different queues or topics within the same transaction.
trans-unit.target: You cannot send messages to different queues or topics within the same transaction.

trans-unit.source: You cannot configure a partitioned queue or topic to be automatically deleted when it becomes idle.
trans-unit.target: You cannot configure a partitioned queue or topic to be automatically deleted when it becomes idle.

trans-unit.source: Azure DocumentDB is a NoSQL database that can store documents.
trans-unit.target: Azure DocumentDB is a NoSQL database that can store documents.

trans-unit.source: A document in DocumentDB is a JSON-serialized representation of an object or other piece of data.
trans-unit.target: A document in DocumentDB is a JSON-serialized representation of an object or other piece of data.

trans-unit.source: No fixed schemas are enforced except that every document must contain a unique ID.
trans-unit.target: No fixed schemas are enforced except that every document must contain a unique ID.

trans-unit.source: Documents are organized into collections.
trans-unit.target: Documents are organized into collections.

trans-unit.source: A collection enables you to group related documents together.
trans-unit.target: A collection enables you to group related documents together.

trans-unit.source: For example, in a system that maintains blog postings, you could store the contents of each blog post as a document in a collection, and create collections for each subject type.
trans-unit.target: For example, in a system that maintains blog postings, you could store the contents of each blog post as a document in a collection, and create collections for each subject type.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, in a multitenant application such as a system that enables different authors to control and manage their own blog posts, you could partition blogs by author and create a separate collection for each author.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, in a multitenant application such as a system that enables different authors to control and manage their own blog posts, you could partition blogs by author and create a separate collection for each author.

trans-unit.source: The storage space allocated to collections is elastic and can shrink or grow as needed.
trans-unit.target: The storage space allocated to collections is elastic and can shrink or grow as needed.

trans-unit.source: Document collections provide a natural mechanism to partition data within a single database.
trans-unit.target: Document collections provide a natural mechanism to partition data within a single database.

trans-unit.source: Internally, a DocumentDB database can span several servers, and DocumentDB may attempt to spread the load by distributing collections across servers.
trans-unit.target: Internally, a DocumentDB database can span several servers, and DocumentDB may attempt to spread the load by distributing collections across servers.

trans-unit.source: The simplest way to implement sharding is to create a collection for each shard.
trans-unit.target: The simplest way to implement sharding is to create a collection for each shard.

trans-unit.source: Each DocumentDB is allocated resources in terms of a performance level.
trans-unit.target: Each DocumentDB is allocated resources in terms of a performance level.

trans-unit.source: A performance level is associated with with a request unit (RU) rate limit.
trans-unit.target: A performance level is associated with with a request unit (RU) rate limit.

trans-unit.source: The RU rate limit specifies the volume of resources that will be reserved for that collection and is available for exclusive use by that collection.
trans-unit.target: The RU rate limit specifies the volume of resources that will be reserved for that collection and is available for exclusive use by that collection.

trans-unit.source: The cost of a collection depends on the performance level selected for that collection; the higher the performance level (and RU rate limit) the higher the charge.
trans-unit.target: The cost of a collection depends on the performance level selected for that collection; the higher the performance level (and RU rate limit) the higher the charge.

trans-unit.source: You can adjust the performance level of a collection by using the Azure management portal.
trans-unit.target: You can adjust the performance level of a collection by using the Azure management portal.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the page <linkText>Performance levels in DocumentDB</linkText><title></title> on the Microsoft website.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the page <linkText>Performance levels in DocumentDB</linkText><title></title> on the Microsoft website.

trans-unit.source: All databases are created in the context of a DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: All databases are created in the context of a DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: A single DocumentDB account can contain several databases, and specifies in which region the databases are created.
trans-unit.target: A single DocumentDB account can contain several databases, and specifies in which region the databases are created.

trans-unit.source: Each DocumentDB account also enforces its own access control.
trans-unit.target: Each DocumentDB account also enforces its own access control.

trans-unit.source: You can use DocumentDB accounts to geo-locate shards (collections within databases) close to the users that need to access them, and enforce restrictions so that only those users can connect to them.
trans-unit.target: You can use DocumentDB accounts to geo-locate shards (collections within databases) close to the users that need to access them, and enforce restrictions so that only those users can connect to them.

trans-unit.source: Each DocumentDB account has a quota that limits the number of databases and collections that it can contain and the amount of document storage available.
trans-unit.target: Each DocumentDB account has a quota that limits the number of databases and collections that it can contain and the amount of document storage available.

trans-unit.source: These limits are subject to change, but are described on the page <linkText>DocumentDB limits and quotas</linkText><title></title> on the Microsoft website.
trans-unit.target: These limits are subject to change, but are described on the page <linkText>DocumentDB limits and quotas</linkText><title></title> on the Microsoft website.

trans-unit.source: Each document must have an attribute that can be used to uniquely identify that document within the collection in which it is held.

trans-unit.source: A collection can contain a large number of documents, in theory only limited by the maximum length of the document ID.
trans-unit.target: A collection can contain a large number of documents, in theory only limited by the maximum length of the document ID.

trans-unit.source: The document ID can be up to 255 characters.
trans-unit.target: The document ID can be up to 255 characters.

trans-unit.source: All operations against a document are performed within the context of a transaction that is scoped to the collection in which the document is contained.
trans-unit.target: All operations against a document are performed within the context of a transaction that is scoped to the collection in which the document is contained.

trans-unit.source: If an operation fails, the work that it has performed is rolled back.
trans-unit.target: If an operation fails, the work that it has performed is rolled back.

trans-unit.source: While a document is subject to an operation, any changes made are subject to snapshot level isolation.
trans-unit.target: While a document is subject to an operation, any changes made are subject to snapshot level isolation.

trans-unit.source: This mechanism guarantees that if, for example, a request to create a new document fails, another user querying the database simultaneously will not see a partial document that is then removed.
trans-unit.target: This mechanism guarantees that if, for example, a request to create a new document fails, another user querying the database simultaneously will not see a partial document that is then removed.

trans-unit.source: DocumentDB queries are also scoped to the collection level.
trans-unit.target: DocumentDB queries are also scoped to the collection level.

trans-unit.source: A single query can only retrieve data from one collection.
trans-unit.target: A single query can only retrieve data from one collection.

trans-unit.source: If you need to retrieve data from multiple collections you must query each collection individually and merge the results in your application code.
trans-unit.target: If you need to retrieve data from multiple collections you must query each collection individually and merge the results in your application code.

trans-unit.source: DocumentDB supports programmable items that can all be stored in a collection alongside documents: stored procedures, user-defined functions, and triggers (written in JavaScript).
trans-unit.target: DocumentDB supports programmable items that can all be stored in a collection alongside documents: stored procedures, user-defined functions, and triggers (written in JavaScript).

trans-unit.source: These items can access any document within the same collection.
trans-unit.target: These items can access any document within the same collection.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, these items execute either inside the scope of the ambient transaction (in the case of a trigger that fires as the result of a create, delete, or replace operation performed against a document), or by starting a new transaction (in the case of a stored procedure that is executed as the result of an explicit client request).
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, these items execute either inside the scope of the ambient transaction (in the case of a trigger that fires as the result of a create, delete, or replace operation performed against a document), or by starting a new transaction (in the case of a stored procedure that is executed as the result of an explicit client request).

trans-unit.source: If the code in a programmable item throws an exception, the transaction is rolled back.
trans-unit.target: If the code in a programmable item throws an exception, the transaction is rolled back.

trans-unit.source: The ability to search for data is often the primary method of navigation and exploration provided by many web applications, enabling users to quickly find resources (for example, products in an ecommerce application) based on combinations of search criteria.
trans-unit.target: The ability to search for data is often the primary method of navigation and exploration provided by many web applications, enabling users to quickly find resources (for example, products in an ecommerce application) based on combinations of search criteria.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Search service provides full-text search capabilities over web content, and includes features such as type-ahead, suggested queries based on near matches, and faceted navigation.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Search service provides full-text search capabilities over web content, and includes features such as type-ahead, suggested queries based on near matches, and faceted navigation.

trans-unit.source: The Search service stores searchable content as JSON documents in a database.
trans-unit.target: The Search service stores searchable content as JSON documents in a database.

trans-unit.source: You define indexes that specify the searchable fields in these documents and provide these definitions to the Search service.
trans-unit.target: You define indexes that specify the searchable fields in these documents and provide these definitions to the Search service.

trans-unit.source: When a user submits a search request, the Search service uses the appropriate indexes to find matching items.
trans-unit.target: When a user submits a search request, the Search service uses the appropriate indexes to find matching items.

trans-unit.source: To reduce contention, the storage used by the Search service can be divided into up into 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, or 12 partitions, and each partition can be replicated up to 6 times.
trans-unit.target: To reduce contention, the storage used by the Search service can be divided into up into 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, or 12 partitions, and each partition can be replicated up to 6 times.

trans-unit.source: The product of the number of partitions multiplied by the number of replicas is called the Search Unit (SU).
trans-unit.target: The product of the number of partitions multiplied by the number of replicas is called the Search Unit (SU).

trans-unit.source: You are billed for each SU that is allocated to your service.
trans-unit.target: You are billed for each SU that is allocated to your service.

trans-unit.source: As the volume of searchable content increases or the rate of search requests grows, you can add SUs to an existing instance of the Search service to handle the extra load.
trans-unit.target: As the volume of searchable content increases or the rate of search requests grows, you can add SUs to an existing instance of the Search service to handle the extra load.

trans-unit.source: The Search Service itself takes responsibility for distributing the documents evenly across the partitions, and no manual partitioning strategies are currently supported.
